Object: Rogers Behavioral Health offers evidence-based treatment for adults, children, and adolescents with a variety of mental health and substance use issues.This program provides:- Outpatient treatment- Partial hospitalization care (PHP)- Intensive outpatient care (IOP)- Residential care- Inpatient care- Specialized therapy- Support groupsConditions treated include:- Depression and other mood disorders- Eating disorders- Addiction- Obsessive-Compulsive and anxiety disorders- Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)Services may vary based on your location. To get started, please call or request a screening appointment through the website. You can call 800-767-4411 for Brown Deer, Oconomowoc, and West Allis, and 888-927-2203 for all other locations. The screening will take approximately 30 to 60 minutes to complete. An intake specialist will ask you a series of questions to offer an appropriate recommendation for the program that best suits your needs. For a children under 18, a representative will ask to speak with a parent or guardian. Rogers Behavioral Health offers financial assistance to patients based on income and household size. Please call 262-303-2180 or visit rogersbh.org/what-expect/financing-your-care/financial-assistance-program for more information about how to apply for financial assistance. Medicare is also accepted.

Object:
The Autism Center for Excellence offers help and hope for your child and family. Whether you wonder if your child may have Autism or are trying to find the best services to help your child make progress after diagnosis, our professional team is here for you every step of the way. SPIN knows that every child will grow and develop to their best potential when professionals and families work in partnership. SPIN’s intervention services focus on building skills with parents, teachers, and community members so that the child will achieve the greatest possible level of independence and community inclusion.

Services:

- Evaluation for autism
- Social skills treatment groups
- Outpatient therapy
- Psychiatric medication management for children and adolescents 
- Applied behavioral analysis (ABA)
- Intensive Behavioral Health Services (IBHS)
- Blended Case Management
- Parent Support Groups

We accept Medicaid for these services.

Object: The Kirkbride Center offers both long- and short-term residential treatment to those facing drug or alcohol addiction. Our goal is to help each individual to formulate coping skills to replace self-destructive behaviors, develop a strong support network and choose to lead an independent, productive life.Services include:- Detoxification- Drug free residential rehabilitation- Treatment for co-occuring disorders- Gender Specific Trauma Recovery (TREM)- Ongoing medication-assisted treatment (MAT) - Pharmacologic blockade- Methadone, buprenorphrine (Suboxone) and naltrexone (Vivitrol) treatment and referralsThe Kirkbride Center accepts Medicaid. Referrals are accepted 24/7 by phone or fax from crisis response and assessment centers, treatment providers (inpatient and outpatient), the Forensic Intensive Recovery Program and the court system, as well as walk-ins. Prior to formal admission, patients will undergo a formal, face-to-face evaluation to gain a full understanding of their background. This is in order to ensure their current needs are fully within the facility’s scope of practice and to place them within the best treatment area for their needs.

Object: CRISIS/MATES provide short–term home and community based intervention services to children and adults who are experiencing a behavioral health crisis. The crisis staff conducts an assessment in the community to determine the appropriate level of care. The teams are prepared to handle a variety of interventions including:- Crisis assessments- Involuntary/voluntary hospitalizations- Linkage with other mental health providers depending on medical coverage- Mobile mental health treatment services (for individuals who are temporarily homebound due to existing medical conditions or specialized mental health disorders)- Emergency psychiatric services for those who are eligibleAll services are confidential and handicap accessible transportation is available. Individuals can be referred to the program by family members, schools, public agencies and/or the Office of Mental Health.

Object:
Mazzoni Center provides a LGBTQ-focused Intensive Outpatient Program (IOP) for alcohol and substance use. This program provides an affirming, safe and respectful treatment opportunity promoting growth and self-discovery.

This program provides:

- Multi-faceted group therapy    
- Aftercare planning
- Individual therapy    
- Medication-Assisted Treatment
- Psychiatric services    
- Peer-based support     
- Peer Recovery support
- Family therapy    
- Relapse prevention    
- Referrals to other Mazzoni Center supportive services

This program is exclusively for LGBTQ people.

We accept most major insurance plans, as well as Medicaid, and some Medicare plans. it is important to understand that all plans vary in coverage. As part of the intake process, they will determine your coverage and cost for IOP. If you are uninsured, we can help determine if you are eligible for special funding, such as Ryan White, to help cover costs. We offer a sliding scale to those who are uninsured and/or not eligible for other coverage.

Object:
Using clinical protocols and activities that promote the concepts of personal strengths and resiliency, these programs combine outpatient psychiatric services with community-oriented psychiatric rehabilitation services.

Members work on skills which will help them achieve a variety of goals ranging from psychiatric symptom reduction to independent living and vocational/educational placement. Our dedicated staff uses a blend of best practices, recovery models, and a person-centered approach that builds coping and socialization proficiency. Services are provided on-site and in a community-based setting. We also offer psychiatric resources in the form of psychiatric evaluations, medication consultation, and medication management.

Members –build off of the development and social maturity of its participants in order to help them actively integrate into local community events and activities.

Object:
Our Outpatient Mental Health Program addresses the behavioral health needs of children, adolescents, and adults. Our highly trained staff uses an array of modalities, including Behavior Modification, Person-Centered, and Trauma-Focused.

The consumer’s treatment goals are tailored to their individual needs. Services may include psychological testing, comprehensive behavioral health evaluation, individual therapy, medication consultation, and management. We employ three adult psychiatrists, one Board Certified Child psychiatrist, and one full-time licensed psychologist who is also a board-certified school psychologist. Our psychologist also facilitates a voluntary clinical supervision group for individuals who seek specialized licensure.

Object: Our Behavioral Health Rehabilitation Service provides holistic, child-centered, and family focused services for school-age children and adolescents with complicated and serious behavioral health needs, including Autistic Spectrum Disorder. The BHRS Department is comprised of a highly trained team of professionals who use a variety of therapeutic skills in a community setting to help consumers achieve their goals. In addition, consumers may be offered, as part of their treatment, psychiatric/ psychological evaluations, psychological testing and medication management conducted by our board certified psychologist and, if appropriate, a board certified child psychiatrist.Services Provided:- In Home Therapeutic Support Staff – Provides the bulk of the BHRS Services administered outside of school by working to redirect the child to more appropriate behaviors or responses based on what is called for in the treatment plan- In School Therapeutic Support Staff – Provides the bulk of the BHRS Services administered during school hours by working to redirect the child to more appropriate behaviors or responses based on what is called for in the treatment plan- Mobile Therapist – Provides individual therapy to the child in a non-traditional setting such as the home or some other community setting- Behavioral Specialist Consultant – Responsible for writing the treatment plan and working with the MT and TSS to implement, update and carry out the objectives of the treatment planEligibility: - Program is for patients age 5 to 13- Must be a Philadelphia residentConsumers are referred to us by CBH. We also accept self referrals.

Object: Recovery support services (RSSs) are nonclinical peer-driven services assisting individuals and families in their recovery from alcohol or drug problems. Services are flexible and may be provided prior to, during, and after treatment.This program provides:- Peer-to-peer services, mentoring, and coaching- Self-help and support groups (PRO-ACT supports all pathways to recovery)- Employment services and job training- Outreach- Relapse prevention- Housing assistance and services- Recovery support activities- Family education- Life skills- Spiritual and faith-based support- EducationThe staff and volunteers are their number one asset. It’s through their integrity, professionalism, and dedication that the message of overcoming and/or avoiding addiction and the services are communicated to those who need them most.Visit, call, or email any of our locations below, or use our Alcohol & Other Drug Information & Recovery Support Line.

Object: The Latina Domestic Violence Program (LDVP) is a free, confidential, and voluntary counseling and advocacy program for victims and survivors of domestic violence. This also includes children who have witnessed domestic violence and teens experiencing domestic violence, ages 4-17 years old. This program provides:- Individual counseling- Safety Planning- Domestic Violence Education for individuals and families- Weekly support groups in English/Spanish for individuals, parents, and children- Linkage to legal advice and representation in family law matters- Emergency relocation and rental/housing assistance- Referrals and linkage to community resources- Advocacy- Remote and In-person services offered at preference of clientCrisis counseling, safety planning, and resources are also available through the Philadelphia Domestic Violence Hotline – 866-723-3014.Friends and family members looking for resources to help a loved one can also contact Congreso de Latinos Unidos for additional support.When calling, please leave a message with a safe phone number and time to call back.

Object:
Using clinical protocols and activities that promote the concepts of personal strengths and resiliency, these programs combine outpatient psychiatric services with community-oriented psychiatric rehabilitation services.

Members work on skills which will help them achieve a variety of goals ranging from psychiatric symptom reduction to independent living and vocational/educational placement. Our dedicated staff uses a blend of best practices, recovery models, and a person-centered approach that builds coping and socialization proficiency. Services are provided on-site and in a community-based setting. We also offer psychiatric resources in the form of psychiatric evaluations, medication consultation, and medication management.

Members develop the skills needed to transition from early to later adulthood. This program works with a forensic population that requires many additional skills as they attempt to move away from an institutional lifestyle.

Object: Behavioral Health Rehabilitation Services, also known as Wraparound, are services for children and adolescents who may be experiencing mental and behavioral health challenges in their daily lives. Wraparound services are a shift from traditional mental health services provided in a therapist’s office, to services where the child normally is, in the home, school, or community. This program provides:- Wraparound services - building constructive relationships and support networks- ReferralMedicaid and Medicare accepted. Private pay available.  Obtaining BHRS services first requires an evaluation by a psychologist. The request is then submitted to CBH (Community Behavioral Health) for an approval. Given the child’s diagnosis, services can be approved for 6 months – 1 year, at a time.

Object: The Children’s Blended Case Management Unit provides assistance for children 6 to 17 years of age (21 years if still enrolled in school) with a behavioral or mental health diagnosis, or intellectual disability in the community or residential treatment facility setting with low, moderate, and severe needs.Services include:- 24 hour-a-day, 7 day-a-week crisis responseThe program’s goals are to connect children to services and resources which will help with their recovery and improvement, collaborate with service providers to monitor consumer participation and satisfaction, help coordinate existing services, and to advocate and provide additional support for the child. The Consortium accepts Medicaid and offers a sliding scale fee for low-income individuals. We don't turn anyone away.

Object: Functional Family Therapy (FFT) is a strength-based model built on a foundation of acceptance and respect. FFT is a short-term, high-quality intervention program with an average of 12 to 14 sessions over three to five months. FFT works primarily with 11 to 18-year-old youth who have been referred for behavioral or emotional problems by the juvenile justice, mental health, school or child welfare systems.Services are conducted in the home settings but not limited to schools, child welfare facilities, probation offices/aftercare systems and mental health facilities. We focus on:- Assessment- InterventionThe Consortium accepts Medicaid and offers a sliding scale fee for low-income individuals. We don't turn anyone away.

Object: STEP is medication-assisted treatment program (MAT) that provides treatment of opioid use disorder. The most commonly prescribed medications in STEP are buprenorphine and naltrexone injections.  We provide:- Administration of buprenorphine typically through weekly appointments, and then incrementally graduating to a minimum of once a month appointments- Naltrexone, a 28-day injection that assists clients with maintaining abstinence from opioidsClients in STEP also:- Receive case management- Engage with a Certified Recovery Specialist- Are required to attend outsourced behavioral health appointments

Object: Esperanza Health Center's Pediatrics Program provides primary care services for children from birth through age 18. Care for children is provided by an excellent team including pediatric and family nurse practitioners, physician assistants, family doctors, and pediatricians.This program provides:- Well Child Visits- Immunizations- Behavioral health consultation - Fitness activities (Hunting Park site) - Social services support - Nutrition counseling- School and Sports PhysicalsEsperanza Health Center accepts Medicaid and Medicare. If you are not eligible for insurance coverage, you may still become an Esperanza patient and apply for discounted care through our Uninsured Patient Program. Under this program, your fee may be anywhere from $20 to $60 for a medical or dental visit. This sliding scale fee is based on your income and family size.Patients of Esperanza Health Center will not be denied access to services due to inability to pay.

Object:
The Open Door Clubhouse is a community-based employment and mental health program. The mission of Open Door Clubhouse is to offer persons with mental health challenges a safe and healing environment wherein each person is given the opportunity to explore their personal and vocational potentials to their fullest, receive support in achieving their goals in employment and education, and achieve their highest level of independence. 

This program provides:

The “Work-Ordered Day” (opportunities to develop job skills in any of several in-house Clubhouse work units ( i.e administrative, food service, janitorial))
• Access to paid employment through its Transitional Employment (TE) and Supported Employment (SE) Programs 
• Assistance with accessing community-based educational resources 
• Opportunities to participate in social and leisure activities
•	Assistance with job placement and job applications
·	Resume writing and interviewing techniques
·	Participation in consensus-based decision-making regarding Clubhouse operations

Object: The Adult Outpatient Services provide assessment, diagnosis, and treatment to individuals requiring mental health or dual diagnosis treatment (treatment of mental health plus substance use). The outpatient treatment team consists of trained professionals including psychiatrists, licensed therapists, psychiatric technicians, counselors, and support staff. Focus areas include mental health and substance use assessment, psychiatric assessment and evaluation for medication, medication monitoring, limited individual counseling, group counseling, bilingual counseling services, interpreter services, benefits services, and community services referral.Common diagnoses for clients at HCCS include disorders of mood, anxiety, personality, addiction and psychosis. HCCS currently offers the following services within the traditional outpatient menu of services:- Psychiatric Evaluation- Medication Managemen- Individual Counseling- Family Therapy- Group Therapy- Psychological Testing and evaluation- Co-occurring Services - Mobile Therapy - Perinatal Depression Treatment servicesHispanic Community Counseling Services accepts Medicare and Medicaid.

The Recovery & Education Center (Wedge Recovery Center)
The Recovery & Education Center (Wedge Recovery Center)
Object: Wedge Recovery Center's Recovery & Education Center (REC) is a day program that combines Outpatient Mental Health Services and Psychiatric Rehabilitation to provide specialized services for individuals who carry a diagnosis of a major mood disorder, a psychotic disorder and/or Borderline Personality Disorder to ensure people in recovery have a safe space to redefine themselves. We offer: - Educational groups- Peer Support- Health, Wellness, and Faith-Based services- Community-based Support and Learning- Individual Therapy and Crisis Support- Group Therapy- Psychiatry (Medication Management)- Co-occurring (Mental Health and Drug & Alcohol) Support- Optional Older Adult ProgramOur ultimate goal is to help a person understand that they are a valued and needed part of society. No person’s recovery journey is the same, therefore there is no standard timeframe on REC services. Scheduling is choice-driven; members choose from the “menu” of services for the days, times, and activities that best fit their personal needs. The Older Adult Program is open on Saturdays, as well.Once a person completes the REC program they are welcome to transition to our Mental Health Outpatient program. If a person wishes to attend REC, they are able to do so right away; there is no waiting time for starting REC services.We accept Medicaid insurance for all of our REC services.

Object: The Anxiety Behaviors Clinic (ABC) provides evaluation, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and medication management for children and adolescents ages 4-18 with primary anxiety disorders, including separation anxiety disorder, phobias, OCD, social anxiety disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. They also provide behavioral treatment for difficulties that frequently present with anxiety disorders, such as sleep problems, selective eating, and tic disorders. The emphasis is on providing evidence-based and empirically supported treatments that involve and engage the whole family.This program provides:- Individual Therapy- Group Therapy

Object: The Caring Together program helps women and their children overcome substance abuse and start a new life without drugs and alcohol. The program utilizes a multiphase, multidisciplinary approach to treat the addiction and any other issues that may have caused or resulted from substance use.This program provides:- Comprehensive treatment needs assessment- Individual and group counseling- Psychiatric evaluation and treatment, including medication-assisted treatment (MAT)- Substance use education including relapse prevention- Trauma-informed care- Anger management classes- Life skills training- Grief and loss groups- DHS evaluations- A safe recovery environment- Access to medical and dental care- Transportation assistance- GED/ABE program referrals- Medical insurance assistance- Employment training referrals- Housing referralsFor women with children, the program offers:- Parenting education- Family reunification assistance- Coordinated case management- Child care during treatment- Child development assessments- Assistance with health care, head-start programs, after-school programs, school-related issues, etc.The program offers a safe recovery environment and is especially beneficial to those who are pregnant or parenting, members of the LGBTQI+ community, and survivors of abuse, as well as anyone experiencing mental health challenges or domestic violence.

Object: The Behavioral Health and Crisis Center serves children with these acute needs and to provide hope and healing in a supportive environment. The Crisis Response Center is a 24/7 walk-in facility that evaluates children 5 to 17 years old with immediate mental health needs and provides short-term therapy so the youth is safe to return home and move into outpatient therapy for follow-up care.This program provides:- Crisis responseWithin the Crisis Response Center is a three-bed Crisis Stabilization Unit for youth who need additional time and treatment to be safe. CHOP provides financial assistance for medically necessary and emergency care to patients who meet the eligibility requirements. If CHOP determines that a patient is eligible, CHOP will waive 100% of the patient’s financial responsibility (after all applicable insurances and other government assistance).

Object:
Oak Street Health's primary care providers serve the specific healthcare needs of older adults on Medicare. 

This program provides: 

- Primary care
- Preventative care
- Mental health services
- Treatment of chronic conditions like diabetes, heart and lung disease, weight management, and depression
- Social activities and events
- 24/7 patient support line

We accept all forms of Medicare, including Original Medicare Part B, select Medicare Advantage plans, Medicare Supplement or Medigap plans and Medicare-Medicaid Plans. 

To schedule an appointment or learn more, please call 888-219-1674 or visit our website.

Object: Einstein Healthcare Network provides liver disease care and transplant services. Their multidisciplinary team of hepatology and transplantation specialists consists of physicians, nurses, researchers, nutritionists, behavioral specialists, social workers and support staff who work closely with patients, families and referring physicians throughout the entire treatment process.This program provides:- Diagnostic testing and treatment- Liver transplantsWhen you contact Einstein for liver disease treatment, a nurse coordinator will arrange a comprehensive evaluation. After your initial visit, any tests and follow-up appointments you need are scheduled for you. Your case is then examined and evaluated each week by your treatment team.Einstein Healthcare Network is dedicated to improving the health of the community it serves, including those who lack the means to pay for services. Qualifying patients may receive free temporary medical treatment through our Financial Assistance process.

Object: The Wedge Substance Abuse Services offer Intensive Outpatient (IOP) and Outpatient (OP) programs. They offer a holistic and individualized approach to treatment with a shared goal of improving the quality of life of members.This program provides:- Group Counseling- Individual counseling- Medication-assisted treatment- Psychiatric evaluation- Case managementThe total length of time in therapy is unique for each person. The staff at the Wedge work to help individuals achieve their goals at the pace that works for each person in treatment. Intakes are offered Monday through Saturday. Urgent requests can often be accommodated quickly. Evening & Saturday group therapy sessions are also available. Medicare and Medicaid accepted. Please verify with insurance provider copays and which substance abuse services are covered. For those that are uninsured, financial help may be available through the Behavioral Health Special Initiative (BHSI) program.

Drug and Alcohol (Substance Use Disorder) Residential Rehabilitation (Horizon House)
Drug and Alcohol (Substance Use Disorder) Residential Rehabilitation (Horizon House)
Object:
At Horizon House we focus on an individual’s re-socialization and engage the entire community—other residents, staff, and social context—as components of treatment. The residential treatment model is a therapeutic community with planned lengths of stay between 6 and 12 months. Addiction treatment focuses on developing personal accountability, responsibility, and living a socially productive life. Treatment is highly structured and may be confrontational at times. Activities are tailored for individuals to examine their damaging beliefs, self-concept, and destructive patterns of behavior, so they may adopt positive, constructive and harmonious ways to treat themselves and others.

Services offered:

- Residential treatment
- Short-term housing
- Recreation and activities
- Substance abuse rehabilitation

We accept Medicare and Medicaid.

Object: Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) is an evidenced-based recovery model designed to provide treatment, rehabilitation, and support services to individuals diagnosed with a serious and persistent mental illness whose needs have not been met by more traditional mental health services. Our ACT teams are interdisciplinary and include specialists in the areas of  psychiatry, mental health, drug and alcohol, vocational training, housing, and nursing. Services include:- Mental health treatment- Rehabilitation- Daily life skills- Employment satisfaction- Living environments and educationThis program accepts Medicare and Medicaid. For more information, please call the nearest office.

Mobile Psychiatric Rehabilitation Service (Horizon House)
Object: Mobile Psychiatric Rehabilitation (MPR) is a service for adults with serious mental illness. Service is provided on site, in the individual’s location of choice, be it their home, school, work or elsewhere in the community. Mobile psychiatry is recovery/resiliency-oriented and time limited aimed at supporting individual functioning levels in four domains: living, learning, socializing and working. This service focuses on skill development and providing support for individuals to live independently in the community of their choice.Services offered:- Psychiatric support- Mobile servicesHorizon House accepts Medicare and Medicaid. Weekend hours are available as needed.For services in Philadelphia County, referrals are only received from Community Behavioral Health (CBH). Please call them at 1-888-545-2600; For services in Delaware County, referrals are made through – Horizon House Psychiatric Rehabilitation Assessment Specialist at 610-876-2403 or intensive case manager, case manager, therapist, Licensed Professional of the Healing Arts, self-referral or Delaware County Base Service Unit.

Object: ACHIEVEability's Family Self-Sufficiency Program (FSSP) offers affordable housing and wrap around coaching supports to families experiencing housing instability. Through FSSP, professional coaches with a background in social work will provide clients with one-on-one counseling and guidance on career, education, financial, parenting, and personal goals. These supports add structure while parents go back to school for a better degree, navigate the start of a career,  establish next steps in housing, and step into a homebuying pipeline to secure generational wealth for their family.

Object:
Our Intensive Behavioral Health Services - Individual Services provide intensive behavioral health support for children and youth between the ages of 3 and 18, who have serious emotional or behavioral issues and their schools and families want on-location services. In some cases, eligibility may extend to age 21 for youth who are still in school and need behavioral support.

This program provides:

- Prescriptions (Written Orders) for IBHS
- Interventions provided in home, school, and/or community
- Behavioral consultations for treatment planning and interventions
- Mobile therapy services
- Behavioral health technician staff

These services are funded by Pennsylvania Medical Assistance and select private insurance health plans.  If you do not have Medical Assistance, we can help with your eligibility.  

Referrals for services can be called into our office by the parent or legal guardian. You do not need a specialty referral from your primary healthcare provider.

Object:
Using clinical protocols and activities that promote the concepts of personal strengths and resiliency, these programs combine outpatient psychiatric services with community-oriented psychiatric rehabilitation services.

Members work on skills which will help them achieve a variety of goals ranging from psychiatric symptom reduction to independent living and vocational/educational placement. Our dedicated staff uses a blend of best practices, recovery models, and a person-centered approach that builds coping and socialization proficiency. Services are provided on-site and in a community-based setting. We also offer psychiatric resources in the form of psychiatric evaluations, medication consultation, and medication management.

Members work on specific issues of aging with a strong focus on health and wellness management.

Community inclusion at the Packer program begins to incorporate organizations that work with an elderly population such as PHILADELPHIA CORPORATION FOR THE AGING along with various neighborhood SENIOR CENTERS.

Object:
CFAR provides a range of therapy services to individuals and families in need. Clients work one-on-one with a therapist for a variety of reasons, ranging from dealing with depression and/or anxiety, previous trauma, major life challenges, personal growth or greater self-understanding.

Services: 

- Individual Therapy
- Family Therapy
- Couples Therapy
- Group Therapy
- Art Therapy
- Play Therapy
- Evidenced Based Practices (Eco-Systemic Structural Family Therapy (ESFT), Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT) and Prolonged Exposure (PE)
- Psychiatric Evaluations and Medication Management

This program accepts Medicaid recipients, and also offers a sliding scale payment plan based on income for uninsured patients.

All initial assessment/intake appointments are being conducted in person.  Once assessed the client has the option to receive in-person or telehealth services at this time.

Object: The Train a Dog Save a Warrior  (TADSAW) program serves the veteran, the family and the community, by providing the warrior with a K-9 rescue ‘Battle Buddy’ and the training and tools needed to become an accredited TADSAW Warrior/Service Dog Team at no charge to the Veteran or the family.Service provided:- Service dog training based on a 15 to 25 week course of Positive Reinforced trainingTADSAW combines the disciplines of occupational, physical, psychopharmaceutical and spiritual therapy in a single program in order to restore and improve the Veteran’s quality of life.  Contact us for additional information or to request an application. After your application has been received, the TADSAW trainer will evaluate your personal dog for viability, or an appropriate candidate from a shelter will be selected if you do not have a dog. We will try to locate trainers within a 60-90 minute driving radius of your home, if not closer.

Object: The CMCT serves children/youth who are experiencing a significant behavioral health crisis.Services include:- Crisis interventionThe team will:- Meet with your child and your family in your home, or school, or community to listen to your/your child’s concerns and understand more about your crisis experience- Provide intensive crisis interventions and de-escalation techniques to help resolve the crisis your child is are experiencing- Conduct an assessment that includes a discussion about your strengths, supports, and resources- Complete a risk assessment to review safety concerns- Develop a safety plan with you and your family- Provide links to appropriate resources, as needed- Follow up with you and your family after the initial crisis responseCMCT services are provided in your home, your child’s school, or your community. Clients will receive a comprehensive assessment which helps to determine the level of service that best meets the needs of you and your family.

Object: Pathways to Recovery is a short-term co-occurring disorder treatment partial hospitalization program for Philadelphia residents with substance use and mental health challenges. Our program works with participants 20 hours per week, for up to nine weeks, with a goal to integrate behavioral and physical health care.We provide a menu of treatment services available each day, including:- Individual, group, and family therapy- Medication assisted treatment (including Suboxone, Vivitrol and Naltrexone)- Medication management with our psychiatrist- Health care coordination - Full-time nursing support- Full-time case management- Full-time peer recovery specialist support- 24/7 on call support to current program participantsThe program works with health clinics, doctors’ offices and other programs and specialists. Pathways to Recovery partners with local Methadone treatment providers for those that suffer from opioid addiction and need both Methadone and partial hospitalization. The program works with the Office of Addiction Services to help place individuals into funded/licensed Recovery Houses and will assist with other housing and social service needs.Program participants must be preapproved by Community Behavioral Health or BHSI. To learn more about the program or make a referral please contact PHMC’s Admissions Coordinator.

Object: NECCBH provides on-site behavioral health services to children and adolescents age 3 to 18 years old who are experiencing mental health or behavioral difficulties. We provide youth and their families with individualized services that promote recovery, resilience and wellness. Services include: - Individual therapy - Family therapy - Group therapy- Psychiatric evaluation- Medication consultation and medication management - Crisis management and intervention services - Inter-agency treatment team meetings Confidential treatment services are provided to assist children and youth with resolving conflicts and overcoming challenges within their home, school and community environments. An emphasis is placed upon person centered and strength based interventions, which help develop new skills and foster resiliency. Staff members will work with each child and family to develop a family centered plan to identify and achieve their personal recovery goals.NECCBH accepts Medicare and Medicaid. An uninsured person who lives in our service area may receive services. The cost for service is based on solely on an individual's ability to pay when not covered by insurance.

Object: Dawn’s Place provides a safe, non-judgmental environment for women affected by commercial sexual exploitation (CSE) or sex trafficking. The residential program is six months long, and can support up to eight women at a time. Each resident works with a social worker to develop a recovery plan and move through the phases of the program. This program provides:- Safe housing- Individual and group therapy (trauma-informed)- Peer mentor support- Art and music therapy- Mindfulness instruction- Help finding housingResidents also have access to health care, education, legal assistance, life skills coaching, career training, nutrition support, access to a fitness area, and connection to additional services, such as addiction or mental health.Please note that this program is not a crisis shelter, please contact Dawn’s Place once you are in a safe place.

Death Doula Services (Philly Death Doula Collective)
Object: PDDC doulas seek to provide care that enables the individual to live as fully as possible, even when the medical prognosis is terminal. Services include:- Assistance with completing advance directives for health care and death care- Assistance with fulfilling final wishes, healing relationships, and/or putting things in order- In-home, hospital, hospice, or nursing home visits- Companion care and caregiver relief/support- Holding space while life-support is discontinued (includes: after-death rituals and body preparation if desired)- Support with stillborn and infant death and bringing baby home for a home funeral- Development of vigil plans- Guided imagery and meditations to help alleviate anxiety and suffering- Continuous bedside presence during the final stages of the dying process- Guidance with after death care of the body and home funerals- Coordinating with funeral homes and assistance with funeral planning- Obituary and eulogy writing support- After death follow-up and grief support- Referral to other community resources as appropriateOur services are built to order, meaning that they extend beyond this list to met the needs of the individual and family we’re serving at that time. Each doula relationship is unique as a result.We utilize a sliding scale pricing structure as we find this most effectively reflects our commitment to providing accessible services.

- Tele-health services
- Site based groups and individual services
- Psychiatric Rehabilitation Services
- Traditional Outpatient Services
- Medication management
-Psychiatry and nursing services

Crisis Text Hotline (THRIVE Llifeline)
Object: THRIVE Lifeline offers a 24/7/365 days Crisis Text Hotline for those experiencing a mental health crisis and who need to chat with a qualified crisis responder. The program offers judgment-free, confidential text messaging to individuals aged 18+ years that focuses on people who are underrepresented (person of color, LGBTQ2S+, person living with disabilities, neurodiverse, and/or other marginalized identities), and experiencing obstacles because of (or simply have questions about) your identities. This program provides:- Mental health text supportPlease text “THRIVE” or 313-662-8209 to begin your conversation with us 24/7/365 days out of the year. Object: National Veterans Wellness and Healing Center is providing week long retreats for veterans, active duty military, reservists, and their significant others who have been diagnosed with PTS (post traumatic stress). This program provides:- Healing retreatsIncluded throughout the week are a mix of Native American healing ceremonies, equine reintegration training, massage, yoga, aroma therapy, acupuncture, art therapy, reiki, along with couples and group counseling sessions. All retreats are a total of seven and a half days. All attendees must commit to the full time period. All lodging, meals and meetings are paid by NVW&HC. Transportation to and from the retreats is the responsibility of the attendees.To apply, fill out an application, then scan and email or mail the application to the organization.

Counseling Support to Nationwide CF Community (Cystic Fibrosis Research Institute)
Counseling Support to Nationwide CF Community (Cystic Fibrosis Research Institute)
Counseling Support to Nationwide CF Community (Cystic Fibrosis Research Institute)
Counseling Support to Nationwide CF Community (Cystic Fibrosis Research Institute)
Object: The Counseling Support to Nationwide CF Community program assists individuals and families struggling with cystic fibrosis.  Through the counseling support program, participants will be provided the guidance, expertise, and support thanks to the help of well versed licensed therapists who understand CF.This program provides:- Individual and family counselingChildren and adults with CF as well as their family members (parents, siblings, spouses/partners) are eligible to receive financial support for six individual therapy sessions per year with a licensed provider of their choice. CFRI will cover the cost of your insurance co-pay for six sessions, or pay up to $120 per session for six sessions if you have no insurance, or your provider does not accept insurance or is outside of your network.You can select a licensed therapist in your community (for a referral, you can ask your CF social worker).This program has limited funds and operates on a “first come first serve” basis. Due to high demand, the program often runs out of funding in the second half of the year. To ensure that your sessions are covered, please follow CFRI program procedures as outlined below:- Check in with CFRI staff: BEFORE sending us any invoices, contracts, or other documents, please contact Sabine Brants ([email protected], 650-665-7576) to check if there is funding available for your sessions. If CFRI has funding available, CFRI staff will send the required paperwork to you as well as your chosen provider. The paperwork provided to you needs to be completed BEFORE starting CFRI-supported sessions. - Wait for sessions to be approved: Once CFRI receives the completed paperwork from you and the provider, CFRI staff will let you know that you are approved to start your six CFRI-supported sessions. This program will not accept invoices that are submitted without prior approval.- Submit assessments and invoices: By participating in the program, you commit to take part in the brief evaluation process. At the first and last of the CFRI-supported sessions, the therapist will ask you to complete two short questionnaires, and submit them to CFRI along with the first and last invoice. Please notify CFRI immediately if you discontinue therapy for whatever reason so the money can be released and used to support other people with CF and their families.For more information on how to participate in CFRI’s Counseling Support Program, please email Sabine Brants: [email protected].

Object: The 24/7 Alzheimer's Helpline provides reliable information and support to all those who need assistance. This program serves people with memory loss, caregivers, healthcare professionals, and the public. This program provides:- 24/7 Alzheimer's HelplineHighly trained and knowledgeable staff can help with:- Understanding memory loss, dementia and Alzheimer's- Medications and other treatment options- General information about aging and brain health- Skills to provide quality care and to find the best care from professionals- Legal, financial and living-arrangement decisionsThe 24/7 Helpline also features:- Confidential care consultation by clinicians who can help with decision-making support, crisis assistance and education on issues families face every day- Help in a caller's preferred language using their translation service that features more than 200 languages and dialects- Referrals to local community programs, services and ongoing supportHelpline staff does not perform diagnosis. Object: The inTransition program is a free, confidential program that offers specialized coaching and assistance for active duty service members, National Guard members, reservists, veterans and retirees who need access to mental health care.This program provides:- An intake process to confirm service members' interest in participating, demographics, and current and gaining provider information, if available- Telephonic coaching sessions using motivational interviewing techniques that empower service members to determine their own paths to continue in care and improve their well-being- Answers to service members' questions about mental health care, treatment methods and techniques, provider types, outcomes measurement, etc.- Information on the use of military support services, community resources and support grouheir service is offered to service members who are: - Relocating to another assignment- Returning from deployment- Transitioning from active duty to reserve component or reserve component to active duty- Preparing to leave military service- Simply in need of a new mental health providerinTransition services are available to all military members regardless of length of service or discharge status and there is no expiration date to enroll. Clients may call and register any day or time, from any location, or you may ask for a referral from your health care provider or case manager.The inTransition program is accessible 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year via a toll-free phone number, email, or online chat.

SAMHSA's National Helpline (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration)
SAMHSA's National Helpline (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration)
Object: SAMHSA’s National Helpline, also known as the Treatment Referral Routing Service, is a confidential, free, 24-hour-a-day, 365-day-a-year, information service, in English and Spanish, for individuals and family members facing mental and/or substance use disorders.This program provides:- Referrals to local treatment facilities, support groups, and community based organizations- Free publications and informationThe service is confidential. SAMHSA will not ask for any personal information. Zip code or other pertinent geographic information may be required in order to track calls being routed to other offices or to accurately identify the local resources appropriate to the person's needs. If a person is seeking treatment and have no insurance or are underinsured, this program will refer them to the state office, which is responsible for state-funded treatment programs. Referrals to facilities that charge on a sliding fee scale or accept Medicare or Medicaid are also available. If a person has health insurance, they are encouraged to contact the insurer for a list of participating health care providers and facilities.The SAMHSA’s National Helpline does not provide counseling.

Object: Penn Medicine's gastroenterology and transplant surgery divisions — as well as radiology, pathology and other departments — all work closely together to ensure a seamless experience for patients with liver disease. A highly skilled professional nursing and technical staff further enhances the patient experience and provides the highest standard of care.This program provides:- Assessment, treatment and management for liver disease and acute liver injury- Treatment and management of chronic viral hepatitis, alcohol-related liver disease, and acute liver injury- Diagnosis and treatment for people with complex liver disease, including: management of intractable ascites, recurrent variceal hemorrhage, hepatic encephalopathy and hepatocellular carcinoma- Transhepatic intravascular portosystemic shunt (TIPSS), performed by interventional radiologists for complications of portal hypertension- Liver transplantsPenn Medicine offers financial assistance for its medical care to eligible individuals and their families. Financial assistance does not take the place of an insurance policy. Generally, you will be eligible for free care if your family's income is below 300% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines. If your family's income is over that limit, you may be eligible for a partial discount, based on your family's income and a full assessment of your situation.

Object:

All CancerCare services are provided by oncology social workers and world-leading cancer experts.

Object: Point Man International Ministries' mission is to connect the hurting veteran as well as their families and friends with others who have already begun the transition home after war. With Jesus Christ as our focal point it is our desire is to provide spiritual and emotional healing through our existing Outpost and Home Front system.Point Man International Ministries (PMIM) are run by veterans from all conflicts, nationalities and backgrounds. Although, the primary focus of Point Man has always been to offer spiritual healing from PTSD, Point Man today is involved in group meetings, publishing, hospital visits, conferences, supplying speakers for churches and veteran groups, welcome home projects and community support.  Just about any where there are Vets there is a Point Man presence. All services offered by Point Man are free of charge.For more information regarding PMIM, please call 800-877-8387 or email Dana Morgan at [email protected].

Adoption and Family Services for Birth Mothers (Lifetime Adoption, Inc.)
Object:
Lifetime Adoption provides support and a wide range of services to women considering adoption for their child (also known as birth mothers). Lifetime Adoption believes that if the Lord has called you to be adoptive parents, they're happy to provide the answers to any Christian adoption questions.

This program provides:

- 24-hour birth mother adoption hotline to answer any questions you may have
- Quality counseling, goal-setting guidance, and confidential help with decision-making
- Compassionate, personalized attention and support, regardless of the decision to adopt or parent
- A nationwide selection of screened and qualified adoptive families who are interested in adopting an infant or older child
- The ability to make an adoption plan for older children
- Access to and information about adoptive families of all religions, race, and ages
- The opportunity to choose the baby’s adoptive parents
- Help with learning about the legal adoption rights of birth fathers
- The option to exchange ongoing letters, photos, and to meet the adoptive family
- Medical, legal, public aid, and housing referrals, including information about child care and health care
- Assistance in avoiding having the children removed from the home by Child Protective Services

This program does not facilitate the adoption themselves.

Online Support Meetings (Postpartum Support International)
Online Support Meetings (Postpartum Support International)
Object:
Perinatal Support International offers online support groups for parents suffering from perinatal mood and anxiety disorders, the most common complication of childbirth. PSI Online Support Group Meetings are led by trained PSI facilitators, and the online groups will connect parents with other parents and provide helpful tools and resources. 

This program provides:
- Online support groups 
PSI provides a variety of free, virtual support groups focusing on perinatal mental health. These include specialized groups for different needs and demographics, such as ADHD, bipolar disorders, birth trauma, and specific support for Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC). There are also groups addressing loss and grief related to early pregnancy, fertility challenges, and stillbirth. Additionally, PSI offers support for diverse family structures and situations, including groups for military families, NICU parents, single parents, and LGBTQIA+ parents.

Please create an account to attend a support group.   Note: PSI peer support groups are free and do not require a Sharewell subscription to attend.

HIV/AIDS Program (HAP) - Medical Case Management (Family Service Association of Bucks County)
HIV/AIDS Program (HAP) - Medical Case Management (Family Service Association of Bucks County)
HIV/AIDS Program (HAP) - Medical Case Management (Family Service Association of Bucks County)
Object:
The Family Service HIV/AIDS Program (HAP) is a gateway service, connecting recently diagnosed individuals and those who have been living with the virus for years, with the tools and resources necessary to achieve ongoing wellness and self-sufficiency. Services are confidential and free of charge.

Services include medical case management and support and education in navigating medical care, medication benefits, treatment adherence and counseling, prevention techniques, support groups, transportation, emergency food & supplements, nutritional information, oral health care. housing and more.

All services are free of charge. To connect with Medical Case Management services, call the Health Information Hotline at 1-800-985-2437. Please mention the HAP program, and state that you are interested in receiving support Family Service. After receiving your referral from the Hotline, a Medical Case Manager will call you within 24 to 48 hours of that referral.

Object:
ROGER is the wellness service of Stop Soldier Suicide (SSS), a veteran-founded and veteran-owned nonprofit.  ROGER provides confidential and personalized suicide-specific care for U.S. veterans and service members, at no cost. ROGER care is tailored to each individual's needs with a focus on preventing suicide and increasing overall wellbeing. The ROGER team can also provide secondary resourcing and referral support while engaged in the program to assist with life stressors that aid in wellbeing.

States Covered: Alabama, California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, New York, Ohio, Oregon, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia.

Face It TOGETHER (face it Together)
Face It TOGETHER (face it Together)
Face It TOGETHER (face it Together)
Object: At Face It TOGETHER, we believe people impacted by addiction, including their loved ones, deserve the same dignity and respect as anyone else affected by a serious illness. Our expert coaches help you discover your path to wellness. If you're a loved one, or struggling with the disease, we're with you every step of the way. Our professional peer coaches help guide you through the challenges you're facing around addiction. Your coach is your wellness partner, providing knowledge, support and skills – or accountability – depending on your needs. We focus on improving every aspect of your life – not just the part that involves drinking or using.You'll receive high-quality, confidential and non-judgmental support from our expert coaches:- Assessments of current strengths, challenges and risks- Personalized addiction management plan and action steps- Weekly coaching sessions- Specialized support for people with the disease and loved ones- Data to track your progress- Convenient options including coaching by video, phone or in person- Unlimited messaging with coach- Connection to resources to support addiction wellness- Navigation to treatment and clinical care as neededFace It TOGETHER has a number of sponsored memberships available for those in financial need. To get started, call or text us at 855-539-9375.

Object: JFCS provides guidance and counseling to individuals, families, and those in interpersonal relationships. Object:
The Bilingual Domestic Violence Program collaborates with other domestic violence programs and the City of Philadelphia to operate the Philadelphia Domestic Violence Hotline which provides the following for victims of domestic and dating abuse:

Services include:

- Crisis intervention 
- Counseling
- Safety planning
- Referrals for domestic abuse services and other needs

The hotline is toll free and is answered by trained counselors 24-hours a day and offers services in multiple languages. The hotline is also covered by local agencies Congreso de Latinos, Women in Transition, and Women Against Abuse.

Subject: Coaching Into Care (Veterans Health Administration)
Coaching Into Care (Veterans Health Administration)
Coaching Into Care (Veterans Health Administration)
Coaching Into Care (Veterans Health Administration)
Object: Coaching Into Care is a national telephone service of the U.S. Dept. of Veterans Affairs (VA) which aims to educate, support, and empower family members and friends who are seeking care or services for a Veteran. Our goal is to help Veterans, their family members, and other loved ones find the appropriate services at their local VA facilities and/or in their community. We also provide coaching to family and friends of Veterans who see that a Veteran in their life may be having difficulty adjusting to civilian life. Coaching is provided by licensed psychologists or social workers, free-of-charge. Coaching involves helping our callers figure out how to motivate the Veteran to seek treatment. We can help you get information about mental health, services at the VA and tips on how to begin the conversation about treatment with a loved one who is a Veteran.What to expect: When you call Coaching Into Care at 888-823-7458, you will talk with a member of our team who specializes in helping callers determine the best way to help the Veteran they care about and how to navigate the VA system. Our hours of operation are Monday — Friday, from 8 AM to 8 PM (Eastern).Calls with a coach vary in length, but generally take 10 to 30 minutes, depending on the issue. Our work with you may extend for several calls and usually with the same coach.Coaching Into Care takes your privacy, and that of the Veteran, very seriously. We keep all calls confidential, except for cases in which we act to protect the lives of you, the Veteran, or others.

Subject: Coaching Into Care (Veterans Health Administration)

WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
Object:
Since 2013, the WWP Talk team has provided a listening ear and a safe, nonjudgmental outlet for warriors and their family members. Our team is committed to you and will collaborate set goals aimed at processing and overcoming challenges. During your participation, you’ll build resilience, develop coping skills, reduce stress levels, and achieve goals that will improve your quality of life. Many who participate in the program also develop improved relationships with friends and loved ones. Our goal-setting model is not only beneficial while participating in the program but can be applied to daily life situations well after you have completed the program.

WWP Talk is a free nonclinical, telephonic, emotional support and goal-setting program. The program helps both warriors and family members plan individualized paths toward personal growth. Participants work one-on-one with a dedicated team member during weekly emotional support calls. Together, they set tangible SMART goals and develop skills that lead to positive changes, like increased resilience, improved psychological well-being, and improved overall quality of life.

To join the program, you must first register with us. For more information or to sign up for the program, call our Resource Center at 888.WWP.ALUM (997.2586) or 904.405.1213.

Subject: WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)

WWP Talk (Wounded Warrior Project)
Object: This program covers residents of All US states and territories.

It’s most appropriate for those who are not experiencing a crisis and who are ready to discuss emotional issues and set goals leading to improved mental health.', 'WWP Talk provides nonclinical emotional support and isn’t meant to take the place of any clinical treatment, therapy, or counseling you may be receiving.']

Object:
Lime Counseling offers individual and couples therapy in order to help people manage a variety of life situations more effectively.  Common areas of support are in Anxiety, OCD, Depression,  Abuse, Stress/Burnout/Feeling Overwhelmed, Adjustments, and Relational Problems.  We also specialize in Sensory Processing Disorder. 

This program provides:

- Counseling services
-Supportive Services
-Consultation Services

Common clinical modalities utilized include:

- Client Centered
- Solution Focused
- CBT
- Trauma Focused CBT
- DBT techniques
- Internal Family Systems
- ACT
- Exposure Response

Sessions are available by phone, video, or text. Reduced/low cost counseling services are available to those in need.
